bibl.title: Fletcher Decker v. State of Washington. Letter.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image.

div1.p: GOVERNMENT OF THE PROVINCE OF SASKATCHEWAN DEPARTMENT OF THE ATTORNEY-GENERAL
ADDRESS YOUR REPLY TO THE DEPUTY ATTORNEY-GENERAL REGINA, SASK. AND REFER TO OUR FILE NUMBER DO NOT WRITE ABOUT MORE THAN ONE SUBJECT IN ANY LETTER

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your favour of the 27th ultimo requesting that I give you some official statement showing that Fletcher Decker against whom extradition proceedings were taken at Seattle for his return to Canada for trial upon a charge of theft of about three hundred bushels of flax, the property of Claude Ficklin, alleged to have been committed near Wiwa Hill Post-office, in the Province of Saskatchewan, on or about the 15th day of November, 1915, has surrendered himself into the custody of the Police Authorities of the Dominion of Canada.

I note that you refer to a letter which you state you wrote to this Department on January 27th, 1922, to which you state you received no reply. It appears also that you enclose a copy of a letter dated February 20th, 1922, from the Deputy Minister of Justice, Ottawa, Ontario, to whom you state you wrote in the first instance, who it appears advised you to communicate directly with me. It appears that you desire the official statement above referred to for the purpose of obtaining an order from the Court at Seattle cancelling the bond which was given when Fletcher Decker was released, pending the hearing of his appeal.
In reply I have the honour to state that the man
Messrs. Beeler and Sullivan Lawyers, 1807 L.C. Smith Building, Seattle, Washington, U.S.A.

the man representing that he ws Fletcher Decker who surrended himself to the Saskatchewan Provincial Police on or about February 2nd, 1922, at the City of Regina, has had a preliminary hearing at which he was confronted by the witnesses for the prosecution who were able to identify him, and after the evidence for the prosecution had been given before the Magistrate he was duly committed for trial, and I am informed that the said accused is the Fletcher Decker against whom the ex- tradition proceedings above referred to were instituted by this Department.

With regard to the letter which you state you wrote to this Department on January 27th, 1922, I may state that your letter of February 27th, 1922, is the first communication in this case which appears to have been received from you in this Department, and your previous letter does not appear to have been received by this Department.

I have the honour to be, Sirs, Your obedient servent,
Deputy Attorney-General.
Messrs. Beeler and Sullivan Lawyers, 1807 L.C. Smith Building, Seattle, Washington, U.S.A.
